Recommended Reason: Shackleton's legendary ship discovered in 2022, perfectly preserved with all artifacts intact
Supporting Evidence: 3,008 meter deep wreck discovered by Endurance22 expedition with over 25,000 high-resolution photos documenting pristine condition

Location: San Telmo Wreck Remnants, Livingston Island
Recommended Reason: Spanish warship wreck from 1819 with potential naval treasures and 644 crew artifacts
Supporting Evidence: Shipwreck remains discovered in 1960 by Argentine expedition, believed to be San Telmo with naval equipment and personal effects

Location: Scott's Base at Cape Evans, Ross Island
Recommended Reason: Terra Nova Expedition base with scientific equipment, personal artifacts, and supply caches from 1911-1913
Supporting Evidence: Well-preserved hut containing original expedition supplies, scientific instruments, food stores, and personal belongings of Scott's team

Location: One Ton Depot, Ross Ice Shelf
Recommended Reason: Scott's largest supply depot containing over 1 ton of supplies, fuel, and provisions buried under snow
Supporting Evidence: Final major depot laid by Scott expedition containing food, fuel, and equipment; historical significance as intended rescue point

Recommended Reason: Massive layered gabbroic complex containing platinum-group metals, chromium, and other valuable minerals
Supporting Evidence: Geological surveys confirm similarities to South Africa's Bushveld Complex, a major producer of platinum and chromium deposits

Recommended Reason: Extensive coal deposits throughout mountain range, including high-quality bituminous coal seams
Supporting Evidence: Geological surveys confirm significant coal deposits with estimated reserves in billions of tons across multiple mountain ranges

Location: Prince Charles Mountains Iron Ore Deposits
Recommended Reason: Major iron ore deposits near Mackenzie Bay with high-grade magnetite concentrations
Supporting Evidence: Scientific expeditions have documented significant iron, copper, and nickel ore deposits suitable for future extraction

Recommended Reason: Potential offshore petroleum and natural gas reserves in sedimentary basins beneath sea floor
Supporting Evidence: Geological studies indicate thick sedimentary sequences capable of hydrocarbon generation and accumulation

Location: Ross Sea Oil and Gas Fields
Recommended Reason: Continental margin areas with potential for sizable petroleum accumulations in offshore basins
Supporting Evidence: Seismic surveys indicate sedimentary rock thicknesses suitable for petroleum generation in continental shelf areas

Recommended Reason: Extension of South American Andes with copper-rich mineralization and potential gold deposits
Supporting Evidence: Geological correlation with productive Andean copper-gold belt suggests similar mineralization potential throughout peninsula

Recommended Reason: Norwegian whaling factory ship wreck from 1915 with industrial equipment and whale oil processing machinery
Supporting Evidence: Factory ship wrecked within days of Endurance disaster, containing valuable whaling equipment and processed whale products

Recommended Reason: Factory ship sunk in 1906 carrying whaling equipment, copper ingots, and industrial machinery
Supporting Evidence: Ship broke into three sections within seven minutes of hitting reef, valuable cargo scattered across Nansen Banks

Recommended Reason: Geological parallel to Australian gold-producing greenstone belts and platinum-bearing intrusions
Supporting Evidence: Scientific expeditions found antimony, chromium, copper, gold, lead, molybdenum, tin, uranium, and zinc in scattered locations

Location: Cape Crozier Emperor Penguin Eggs Cache
Recommended Reason: Site of Wilson, Bowers, and Cherry-Garrard's winter journey - first emperor penguin eggs collected for science
Supporting Evidence: Historic location where three men collected first emperor penguin eggs in 1911, representing milestone in Antarctic exploration and science

Location: Queen Maud Land Gold Correlation Zone
Recommended Reason: Geological correlation with South Africa's gold-producing Witwatersrand beds suggests similar gold deposits
Supporting Evidence: Geological mapping indicates rock formations similar to world's largest gold-producing region in South Africa
